article.description:
David Noel scored a season-high 21
points and Rashad McCants added 19 as North Carolina shot 64
percent in the second half to beat DePaul 83-72 in the first round
of the NIT on Tuesday night.
article.headline: May ruled out for season with ankle injury
article.linkText: UNC suffers costly victory against DePaul
article.story:
CHAPEL HILL, N.C. (AP) -- David Noel scored a season-high 21
points and Rashad McCants added 19 as North Carolina shot 64
percent in the second half to beat DePaul 83-72 in the first round
of the Owens Corning NIT on Tuesday night.

	   The Tar Heels (18-15), playing in the NIT for the first time in
29 years, overcame a dismal final eight minutes of the first half
to advance to play the winner of the Wyoming-Eastern Michigan game,
which was postponed until Thursday because of a snow storm.

	   Noel, a 6-foot-6 freshman, was 10-for-13 from the field and
added a season-high 11 rebounds. His previous best scoring output
was 19 against Duke on Feb. 5.

	   It was the most points the Blue Demons (16-13) have given up
since a 102-71 loss at Notre Dame on Dec. 14.

	   North Carolina's trapping defense changed the game in the
opening stages of the second half, fueling a 16-3 run in the first
three minutes.

	   DePaul had seven turnovers in less than six minutes as Jawad
Williams, who added 16 points, sank a pair of 3-pointers to turn a
six-point halftime deficit into a 53-42 lead.

	   The margin grew to 14 before the Blue Demons closed to 69-59
with 6:03 remaining. But Williams hit a 3-pointer 17 seconds later
to help seal the victory.

	   Sam Hoskin led DePaul with 24 points, while Andre Brown had 14
points and 16 rebounds for the Blue Demons.

	   Sean May returned to the Tar Heels' lineup against Duke in the
Atlantic Coast Conference tournament semifinals Saturday after
missing 21 games with a broken left foot. But he turned his right
ankle against the Blue Devils and has been ruled out for the rest
of the season.

	   The Tar Heels missed him on the inside as the Blue Demons ruled
the glass.

	   North Carolina had a first half of streaks.

	   The Tar Heels missed their first five shots, made their next six
and then went into an offensive funk over the final 8:29 of the
period, getting just one hoop to fall behind 35-29 at the break.

	   Eight of the team's 10 turnovers came in the final 7½ minutes as
DePaul went on a 15-0 run to grab control and take the crowd out of
the game.

	   Brown dominated the opening 20 minutes inside, logging a
double-double as the Blue Demons held a 27-13 advantage on the
boards.
